p: Turmeric essential oil, with the exception of the radicle elongation of P. oleracea, significantly inhibited both hypocotyl and radicle growth of the selected weeds at all doses (0.125, 0.25, 0.50, and 1 µL/mL) assayed. The hypocotyl development was reduced without significant differences between doses applied to reach percentages of 56.55% ( P. oleracea), 40.45% ( L. multiflorum), 39.33% ( E. crus-galli), 97.83% ( C. selloana), and 86.23% ( N. glauca) ( Table 3). The radicle elongation of L. multiflorum and E. crus-galli was significantly reduced at all doses of turmeric essential oil, reaching 36.74% and 44.41%, respectively, at the highest dose tested. C. selloana was again the most sensitive species to turmeric essential oil with percentages of radicle growth inhibition of 77.32%, 81.44%, 86.08%, and 99.74% at the doses of 0.125, 0.25, 0.50, and 1 µL/mL, whereas N. glauca reached a percentage of 51.42% at the highest dose applied.
